thread.title: Uber and New York City call truce, avoid vote to curb growth
thread.title_full: Uber and New York City call truce, avoid vote to curb growth

author: Michael del Castillo
title: Uber and New York City call truce, avoid vote to curb growth
text:
Uber and New York City officials reached an agreement Wednesday that stops attempts to… more New York City's car wars are over, at least for now. Uber and city officials reached an agreement Wednesday that stops attempts to halt Uber's growth in the five boroughs. The truce ends the increasingly heated dispute that found Mayor Bill de Blasio , the Taxi and Limousine Commission and key members of the City Council on one side of the dispute, facing off against Uber and other e-hail and livery companies as well as Gov. Andrew Cuomo and a growing number of other officials. "The administration, City Council and Uber have agreed to a framework that will advance the city’s vital policy goals for passengers, drivers and the public," Anthony Shorris , first deputy mayor of New York City, wrote in a statement. "It sets in motion a plan to guide a comprehensive and fair public response, driven by data, to the increase in for-hire vehicles. And it ensures that the future growth of this industry matches the values and the interests of New Yorkers." Most importantly, Uber has agreed not to accelerate its growth rate, an estimated 2,000 cars per month, in exchange for the city not attempting to throttle its growth, according to Shorris.
